subsection.title: Introduction
subsection.p: Because logarithms are actually exponents, they have several properties that can be derived from the laws of exponents. Here are the laws we will need at present.

li.p: To multiply two powers with the same base, add the exponents and leave the base unchanged. a^m \cdot a^n = a^{m+n}
To divide two powers with the same base, subtract the exponents and leave the base unchanged. \frac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}
To raise a power to a power, keep the same base and multiply the exponents. \left(a^m\right)^n = a^{mn}

subsection.p: Each of these laws corresponds to one of three properties of logarithms.
We will consider proofs of the three properties of logarithms in the Homework problems. For now, study the examples below, keeping in mind that a logarithm is an exponent.

subsection.title: Using the Properties of Logarithms
subsection.p: Of course, these properties are useful not so much for computing logs but rather for simplifying expressions that contain variables. We will use them to solve exponential equations. But first, we will practice applying the properties. In the following Example, we rewrite one log in terms of simpler logs.

statement.p: Simplify ~~\log_{b}\sqrt{{xy}}.

solution.p: First, we write \sqrt{xy} using a fractional exponent: \log_{b}{xy} = \log_{b}{(xy)^{1/2}} Then we apply Property (3) to rewrite the exponent as a coefficient: \log_{b}{(xy)^{1/2}} = \frac{1}{2}\log_{b}{(xy)} Finally, by Property (1) we write the log of a product as a sum of logs: \frac{1}{2}(\log_{b}{xy}) = \frac{1}{2}(\log_{b}{x} + \log_{b}{y}) Thus, ~~\log_{b}\sqrt{xy} = \dfrac{1}{2}(\log_{b}{x} + \log_{b}{y}).

statement.p: Simplify \log_{b}\dfrac{x}{y^2}.
Answer: \log_b+\cdot\log_b
Simplify \log_{b}\dfrac{x}{y^2}.

subsection.p: We can also use the properties of logarithms to combine sums and differences of logarithms into one logarithm.

statement.p: Express ~~3(\log_b x - \log_b y) as a single logarithm with a coefficient of 1.

solution.p: We begin by applying Property (2) to combine the logs. 3(\log_b x - \log_b y) = 3 \log_{b}\left(\frac{x}{y}\right) Then, using Property (3), we replace the coefficient 3 by an exponent 3. 3 \log_{b}\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)=\log_{b}\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)^3

statement.p: Express 2\log_b x + 4\log_{b}{(x + 3)} as a single logarithm with a coefficient of 1.
Answer: \log_b

subsection.title: Solving Exponential Equations

warning.p: Do not confuse the expression ~\dfrac{\log_{10}{7}}{\log_{10}{5}}~ with ~\log_{10}{\left(\dfrac{7}{5}\right)}; they are not the same!

Property (2) allows us to simplify ~\log{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)}, but not ~\dfrac{\log x}{\log y}. We cannot rewrite ~\dfrac{\log_{10}{7}}{\log_{10}{5}}, so we must evaluate it as ~(\log 7)/(\log 5). You can check on your calculator that \dfrac{\log_{10}{7}}{\log_{10}{5}}\ne \log_{10}{\left(\dfrac{7}{5}\right)}= \log_{10}{1.4}.

statement.p: How can we solve ~4^x=60?

li.p: Take log base 10 of both sides.

solution.p: First we divide both sides by 80 to obtain 20.5 = 6^{0.03x} Next, we take the base 10 logarithm of both sides of the equation and use Property (3) of logarithms to get \log_{10}{20.5} = \log_{10}{6^{0.03x}}= 0.03x \log_{10}{6} On the right side of the equation, x is multiplied by two constants, 0.03 and \log_{10}{6}. So, to solve for x we must divide both sides of the equation by 0.03 \log_{10}{6}. We use a calculator to evaluate the answer: x = \frac{\log_{10}{20.5}}{0.03 \log_{10}{6}}\approx 56.19 (On your calculator, remember to enclose the denominator, 0.03 \log_{10}{6}, in parentheses.)

subsection.title: Applications
subsection.p: By using the properties of logarithms, we can now solve equations that arise in exponential growth and decay models, no matter what base the exponential function uses.

statement.p: The population of Silicon City was 6500 in 1990 and has been tripling every 12 years. When will the population reach 75,000?

solution.p: The population of Silicon City grows according to the formula P(t) = 6500 \cdot 3^{t/12} where t is the number of years after 1990. We want to find the value of t for which P(t) = 75,000; that is, we want to solve the equation \begin{aligned}[t] 6500 \cdot 3^{t/12} \amp = 75,000\amp\amp \blert{\text{ Divide both sides by 6500.}}\\ 3^{t/12} \amp = \frac{150}{13} \end{aligned} Now we take the base 10 logarithm of both sides and solve for t. \begin{aligned}[t] \log_{10}{(3^{t/12})} \amp = \log_{10}\left(\frac{150}{13}\right) \amp\amp \blert{\text{Apply Property (3).}}\\ \frac{t}{12}\log_{10}{3} \amp= \log_{10}\left(\frac{150}{13}\right) \amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide by }\log_{10}{3}\text{; multiply by 12.}}\\ t \amp = \frac{12 \left(\log_{10}{\dfrac{150}{13}}\right)}{\log_{10}{3}}\\ \amp\approx 26.71 \end{aligned} The population of Silicon City will reach 75,000 about 27 years after 1990, or in 2017.

subsection.title: Compound Interest
subsection.p: The amount of money in an account that earns interest compounded annually grows exponentially according to the formula A(t) = P(1 + r )^t (See to review compound interest.) Many accounts compound interest more frequently than once a year. If the interest is compounded n times per year, then in t years there will be nt compounding periods, and in each period the account earns interest at a rate of \dfrac{r}{n}. The amount accumulated is given by a generalization of our earlier formula.

statement.p:
Rashad deposited $1000 in an account that pays 4% interest. Calculate the amount in his account after 5 years if the interest is compounded
semiannually
quarterly
monthly

li.p: Semiannually means "twice a year,"" so we use the formula for compound interest with P = 1000, r = 0.04, n = 2, and t = 5. \begin{aligned}[t] A(5) \amp = 1000\left(1 + \frac{0.04}{2}\right)^{2(5)} \\ \amp = 1000(1.02)^{10} = 1218.99 \end{aligned} If interest is compounded semiannually, the balance in the account after 5 years is $1218.99.

Quarterly means "4 times a year,"" so we use the formula for compound interest with P = 1000, r = 0.04, n = 4, and t = 5. \begin{aligned}[t] A(5) \amp = 1000\left(1 + \frac{0.04}{4}\right)^{4(5)} \\ \amp = 1000(1.01)^{20} = 1220.19 \end{aligned} If interest is compounded quarterly, the balance in the account after 5 years is $1220.19.

There are 12 months in a year, so we use the formula for compound interest with P = 1000, r = 0.04, n = 12, and t = 5. \begin{aligned}[t] A(5) \amp = 1000\left(1 + \frac{0.04}{12}\right)^{12(5)}\\ \amp = 1000(1.003)^{60} = 1221.00 \end{aligned} If interest is compounded monthly, the balance in the account after 5 years is $1221.

subsection.title: Solving Formulas
subsection.p: The techniques for solving exponential equations can also be used to solve formulas involving exponential expressions for one variable in terms of the others.

statement.p: Solve ~~2C = Cb^{kt}~~ for t. (Assume that C and k \ne 0.)

solution.p: First, we divide both sides by C to isolate the power. b^{kt} = 2 Next, we take the log base 10 of both sides. \begin{aligned}[t] \log b^{kt} \amp = \log 2 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Apply Log Property (3).}}\\ kt \log b \amp = \log 2 \end{aligned} Finally, we divide both sides by k \log b to solve for t. t = \frac{\log 2}{k \log b}
